Ethereum has given us openness, but it hasn’t given us way to defend itself in time. 

That’s the gap @DroseraNetwork is trying to fill.

Drosera describes itself as the immune system for Ethereum. 

Instead of waiting for humans to react, it builds a decentralized network that can detect threats and respond automatically. 

The core idea is simple but powerful: developers create “Traps”, smart contracts that define conditions to watch for and actions to take if they’re triggered. 

Then a network of “Operators” monitors those Traps and executes them in a trustless way.

Think of it like this: if liquidity in a lending protocol suddenly collapses, a Trap could pause the protocol before attackers drain the rest. 

If a governance parameter changes in a suspicious way, a Trap could alert the community or even stop execution until verified. 

In other words, Drosera gives protocols something they’ve always lacked which is reflexes.

The use cases go far beyond exploits. Lending, stablecoins, bridges, treasuries, governance, insurance, oracles, anything that depends on live on chain data can benefit from automated monitoring and response. 

And because Drosera provides dev tools like Foundry templates, CLI installers, and docs, setting up Traps doesn’t require being a security researcher. It’s designed to be accessible.

What stands out about Drosera is the framing. 

We always talk about blockchains as resilient, unstoppable systems. But the reality is, DeFi today is fragile. One bug, one exploit, and years of work can collapse. 

Drosera is betting that the next evolution isn’t just faster chains or better UX, but a network that protects itself the way a body fights off infection.

If Ethereum is the brain and heart of Web3, Drosera is aiming to be its immune system.

El pentesting no termina con un PDF ni con el cierre de unas cuantas vulnerabilidades.
El verdadero valor está en el seguimiento posterior, ese trabajo silencioso que garantiza que las mejoras implementadas sean efectivas y duraderas.
Un buen seguimiento implica:

Verificación periódica de que las soluciones aplicadas siguen funcionando con el tiempo y que no se han reintroducido fallos.

Monitoreo proactivo para detectar nuevas amenazas que puedan aprovechar debilidades similares.

Retroalimentación continua con los equipos técnicos y de gestión para afinar procesos, herramientas y políticas.

Documentación de evolución, mostrando cómo ha mejorado la postura de seguridad de la organización después del pentesting.

💡 Mentalidad de hacker profesional:
Un test de penetración sin seguimiento es como cerrar la puerta pero dejar la llave puesta del lado de afuera. El seguimiento convierte la reacción en prevención y transforma un informe en una estrategia de seguridad viva.

El pentesting no es solo “romper cosas” y mostrar capturas.
El verdadero valor está en cómo ayudamos a que esas brechas se cierren.
Si solo encontramos vulnerabilidades y no se hace nada después, el trabajo queda incompleto y el riesgo sigue ahí.
La remediación es la fase posterior a la entrega del informe.
En este momento, trabajamos junto al equipo del cliente para:
Priorizar vulnerabilidades según su criticidad.

Implementar las correcciones o parches necesarios.
Validar que la solución realmente funciona (retesting).

💡 Importante:
Un informe sin seguimiento puede terminar olvidado en un cajón, y eso es lo peor que puede pasar.
El objetivo es reforzar la seguridad y prevenir incidentes futuros, no solo documentar los problemas.

Un buen hacker no solo detecta fallas, también ayuda a cerrarlas y blindar la infraestructura.

Hasta ahora vimos técnicas, herramientas y ataques. Pero todo eso no sirve de nada si no sabemos comunicar los resultados de forma clara y profesional. Por eso, vamos a hablar de los tipos de informes en un proceso de ethical hacking o pentesting.

El informe es el único entregable tangible que recibe el cliente después de una prueba de intrusión. Puede que hayamos hecho magia durante el análisis, explotado vulnerabilidades críticas o detectado fallas que nadie había visto antes… pero si el informe está mal presentado, mal redactado o no se entiende, todo ese trabajo se pierde.

Un buen informe de seguridad tiene que lograr tres cosas:

Ser comprensible para un ejecutivo que no es técnico.

Ser útil para un administrador o desarrollador que tiene que solucionar las vulnerabilidades.

Generar impacto, es decir, dejar claro por qué esas fallas representan un riesgo real para el negocio.

¿Y qué tiene que incluir? Como mínimo:

Un resumen ejecutivo donde se detalle el alcance de la auditoría, las metodologías utilizadas, los activos analizados y una visión general de los hallazgos.

Una clasificación de las vulnerabilidades según su severidad (por ejemplo usando CVSS), y priorizadas por impacto.

Una sección técnica con detalles de cada hallazgo, incluyendo:
Evidencias (capturas, logs, hashes, etc.)
Explicación del riesgo
Reproducción paso a paso del fallo
Recomendaciones específicas para remediación

Y finalmente, un apéndice con referencias, herramientas utilizadas, versión de plugins (como en Nessus), o cualquier información complementaria.

El escaneo que ves en pantalla —que ya vimos antes— se puede usar como base para generar informes personalizados desde Nessus, pero no deberíamos entregar ese mismo resultado crudo al cliente. Es nuestra responsabilidad traducir esos datos en un lenguaje que tenga sentido para el negocio.

Por ejemplo, no es lo mismo decir:

HANA vs Solana Architecture Comparison for Web3 Infrastructure 👀

HANA in a Nutshell 
HANA is built on the Cosmos SDK and enables cross-chain interoperability with the Hana Gateway
It uses ZKP and TSS for security and privacy in peer-to-peer marketplaces to keep user data safe and the user experience simple

Solana in a Nutshell
Solana focuses on performance by combining Proof of History and Proof of Stake. It has very high throughput and is suitable for transaction-intensive apps like DeFi and NFT, although intermittent outages have raised questions about stability in the past

A Practical Scenario
Let’s say you’re building a simple payment system
With @HanaNetwork and modules like Hanafuda and Gateway, cross-chain integration is easy and the user interface is straightforward
On Solana, speed is impressive, but setting up and managing nodes can be more complex

Technical Summary
HANA’s focus is on privacy and cross-chain interoperability
solana focuses on speed and processing power. HANA distributes signing authority via TSS and enhances privacy with ZKP
Solana runs at scale with a large number of validators and is suitable for large workloads
The final choice depends on your priorities; if privacy and interchain interaction are more important, HANA is a more logical choice, if you want the most efficiency on a single chain Solana is ahead

Black Dog (2024)
Mêlant western, film noir et critique sociale, Black Dog suit Ah Lang (Eddie Peng), un ex-taulard revenu dans sa ville natale en marge du désert de Gobi, alors que la Chine se prépare à accueillir les JO de Pékin 2008.
Alors que les JO doivent donner au monde l’image la plus éclatante du pays, le réalisateur choisit au contraire de s’attarder sur ses marges : paysages calcinés, murs décrépits, affiches effilochées.
Derrière le destin d’un homme et d’un chien se dessine ainsi une radiographie de la Chine contemporaine, entre fierté nationale et fractures sociales.
Mais c’est aussi l’histoire d’un duo : Ah Lang et son chien, tous deux blessés, farouches, mais porteurs d’une noblesse fragile. Dans leur rencontre naît une forme de rédemption mutuelle.
Une histoire de survie et de solitude, qui transforme le parcours d’un homme et d’un chien errant en reflet des exclus d’une Chine lancée à toute vitesse vers l’avenir.
Cette dimension sociale s’accompagne d’une vraie retenue et sobriété émotionnelle tout en gardant le bon équilibre entre dureté et tendresse. Ni larmoyant ni cynique, Black Dog est un film dur, mais profondément humain.

Why Morph is Unique

Speed: Finality in 1–2 days vs. 7 days in traditional Optimistic Rollups.
Efficiency: zk-proofs are used only in disputes, reducing overhead.
Security: zk-proof fallback ensures cryptographic validity.
Decentralized Sequencers: Eliminates single points of failure and boosts censorship resistance.
Modular Design: Supports easy upgrades and a future-proof structure.
Hybrid Rollup Model: Combines Optimistic Rollup speed with zk-rollup security for optimal performance.

Who Runs the Network?

MorphLayer is powered by a decentralized network of participants that ensure speed, security, and transparency. Sequencers form the backbone, executing, ordering, and submitting transactions. Provers generate zk-proofs whenever a batch is challenged, while Validators (Challengers) verify states and contest invalid transactions. Nodes maintain a read-only copy of the network, keeping data synchronized and transparent. At the base, Ethereum (L1) provides ultimate settlement and finality, securing the entire system.

What's MorphLayer?

MorphLayer is a permissionless, EVM-compatible Layer-2 network on Ethereum, built with an optimistic zkEVM hybrid model. It offers the speed and affordability of optimistic rollups combined with the security of zk-proofs. It’s also notable as the first L2 on Ethereum deploying a decentralized sequencer from day one.

Anyone, even on consumer hardware, can generate these ZKPs, meaning no central party controls cross-chain activity, and no censorship can creep in. Once verified, whole batches of transactions are instantly settled across chains. 

It’s consensus itself, proven in zero-knowledge, designed to run permissionlessly into infinity. ♾️

#threatreport:
The CORNFLAKE.V3 backdoor, part of a campaign associated with the threat groups UNC5518 and UNC5774, has been under investigation by Mandiant Threat Defense since mid-2024. UNC5518 predominantly exploits legitimate websites by serving fake CAPTCHA verification pages to distribute a downloader script, initiating a malware infection chain. This financial-driven group often collaborates with other actors who utilize the access gained for further malicious deployments.

CORNFLAKE.V3 manifests in two variations, written in either JavaScript or PHP. It retrieves payloads through HTTP, allowing it to execute various file types, including shell commands, executables, and dynamic link libraries (DLLs). The backdoor is capable of gathering basic system information and transmitting it to a remote server, with the added capability to misuse Cloudflare Tunnels to proxy traffic. The malware has shown a capacity for persistence and can ensure that only one instance is running concurrently.

Upon execution, CORNFLAKE.V3 performs initial checks and collects system information before establishing a connection to its command-and-control (C2) server. It utilizes two lists (hosts and hostsIP) to manage its communication, attempting to connect to random entries from these lists. The main function of the backdoor sends an initial POST request to the C2 server, carrying encrypted system information and execution results. For persistence, it leverages the command-line arguments of the "node.exe" process, extracting and writing the initial malicious script to a log file in the Node.js installation directory.

The malware can execute a variety of payloads. Notably, it has been observed conducting Active Directory reconnaissance, which includes activities such as counting the number of computer objects in a domain, displaying detailed user context, enumerating domain trusts, listing domain controllers, and querying service principal names (SPNs). The second significant capability is Kerberoasting, where it queries for user accounts associated with SPNs to harvest credentials. Password hashes obtained through this technique are exfiltrated to the C2 server for potential cracking.

A recent variant of CORNFLAKE.V3 implemented in PHP has emerged, maintaining similar functionalities as the original Node.js version. Additionally, after interactions with the C2 server, the backdoor retrieves a DLL payload, specifically the WINDYTWIST.SEA backdoor, which is then executed, further expanding its capabilities in the compromised environment.

The investigation underscores the collaborative dynamics of modern cyber threats, illustrating how UNC5518 capitalizes on compromised sites while other groups like UNC5774 deploy versatile malware to further operational goals. The focus on reconnaissance and credential theft suggests a clear intention for lateral movement within targeted networks, emphasizing the evolving complexity and danger posed by such threat actors.

Developers disable copy/paste in password fields mainly for security: to prevent malware from stealing clipboard contents or accidental leaks by pasting elsewhere. It also supports keystroke analysis for authentication and ensures correct typing on change forms.

If allowed, risks include clipboard snooping by malware, unintended exposure if forgotten in clipboard, or pasting errors. However, experts note this practice often reduces overall security by hindering password managers, leading users to weaker passwords.

#threatreport:
ESET identified a zero-day path traversal vulnerability in WinRAR (CVE-2025-8088) exploited in weaponized RAR archives that dropped a malicious DLL named msedge.dll. The flaw affected WinRAR 7.12 and any software using publicly available Windows UnRAR.dll or its source code that had not updated dependencies. The vulnerability was reported July 24, 2025 and patched in WinRAR 7.13 (beta published same day; full release July 30, 2025).

Targeting occurred via spearphishing (July 18–21, 2025) against financial, manufacturing, defense and logistics organizations in Europe and Canada using CV-themed attachments. ESET telemetry indicated the actor did not successfully compromise observed targets. Activity is attributed to RomCom (aka Storm-0978/UNC2596/Tropical Scorpius) based on region, TTPs and tooling; RomCom is known to deploy backdoors capable of command execution and modular downloads. A second threat actor also exploited CVE-2025-8088 independently.

Three distinct execution chains were observed. The Mythic agent chain used a malicious LNK (Updater.lnk) to add HKCU\SOFTWARE\Classes\CLSID\{1299CF18-C4F5-4B6A-BB0F-2299F0398E27}\InprocServer32 = %TEMP%\msedge.dll, leveraging COM hijacking of the PSFactoryBuffer CLSID present in npmproxy.dll so that any process loading it (e.g., Edge) executes the DLL. The DLL AES-decrypts embedded shellcode and enforces a target check by comparing the machine domain name to a hardcoded value, exiting if mismatched.

A SnipBot variant used Display Settings.lnk to run %LOCALAPPDATA%\ApbxHelper.exe, a modified PuTTY CAC binary signed with an invalid certificate. The loader uses the filename as a key to decrypt strings and shellcode; execution is gated by an anti-analysis check requiring a specific RecentDocs registry value count (sample checked for registry value name "68", i.e., >=69 documents). If passed, shellcode downloads the next stage from https://t.co/LAQqlYufM6.

A third chain used Settings.lnk to execute %LOCALAPPDATA%\Complaint.exe (RustyClaw downloader in Rust, also with an invalid cert) which fetched a payload (SHA-1 01D32FE88ECDEA2B934A00805E138034BF85BF83, internal name install_module_x64.dll) from https://t.co/C7uTdCcIz8; observed MeltingClaw C2 was https://t.co/OgpIx4dld5.

I think men are naturally more romantic than women. 

Sure women enjoy romance more, and anticipate it with more vulnerability, but they aren’t themselves as romantic in their attitude and actions. 

Scientifically, research shows that men fall in love faster, fall out of love slower, and only initiate 20% of divorces. 
Socially, we know that most romantic interactions are initiated by the man, which is preferable to most women anyway. 
And logically we can just realize that most traditionally romantic gestures are things men do for women, and not the other way around. Men approach women, buy flowers, serenade, reserve and pay for dinner, open the door, pull out the chair, and they propose. 
Women are expected to do a lot of things too, and it takes great work, dedication and discipline to be a fine woman, but there’s very few traditionally romantic gestures that I am aware of that a woman does for a man. She bakes food, gives praise, and then generally just accepts a man’s gestures with grace, humility and gratitude. 

Now if I met a woman that actually did all those things, I would marry her immediately, so again there is great value in what women do. The point of my post here is just that I find it strange that women are painted as the more romantic sex. I think romance is inherently a masculine trait, and that femininity is actually a response to romance. 

I think this is why women love romance novels and men are mostly unimpressed by them; women yearn to experience romance, while men yearn to express it. 
Most women are uncomfortable with giving a compliment to a man, and yet they dream of being complimented. Most men are uncomfortable being complimented, and yet they dream of complimenting a woman and being heard, acknowledged and given just the satisfaction of knowing it improved her day; not that compliments are a great indicator of romance but the social behavior is still there. 

So, tldr, men need to reclaim their roles as romantic, vulnerable partners, and women need to stfu and adopt more grace and humility.

Undeclared deps in Homebrew happen when formulas assume system libs (e.g., specific OpenSSL or Ruby) without listing them, leading to install failures if absent or mismatched—common on macOS upgrades.

2024 audit (2023 Trail of Bits report): 25 issues, 16 fixed, 3 in progress, 6 acknowledged. Unfixed include sandbox escapes via string injection/socket pivot, unsandboxed archive extraction, and permissive rules.

No public 2025 Homebrew audit found.

MacPorts provides stronger isolation and older macOS support as an alternative.

SOS (B&W) # 2

Authenticated using a simple and secure, immutable, ERC 721 Smart Contract from Openzeppelin. Metadata stored using the IPFS protocol. Individual CID V1. 

In the metadata file you can find the address of the smart contract, the chain, a reference to the Token ID and a description of the collection. Several copies of the metadata file and the photo have been stored off-chain. This information on the metadata is there for you to identificate the NFT without any platform or marketplace. Just an IPFS node and a block explorer/ethereum node.

What makes this a story worth telling isn't just the failure, but the response.

Gamma didn't hide. They published a detailed, honest post-mortem. They admitted the error was theirs. They hired OpenZeppelin for a post-incident audit.

And they are using their future revenue to make every single user whole. This is how you build trust from the ashes of a disaster. It's a lesson in engineering culture, not just code.

To check for unauthorized logins on X:

1. Go to Settings and privacy > Your account > Download an archive of your data. This includes login history—request it, then download when ready.

2. Check Settings and privacy > Security and account access > Apps and sessions for active devices; log out unfamiliar ones.

Suspicious login notifications occur for unusual activity like new devices or locations. If it's not you, change your password immediately and enable two-factor authentication via Settings > Security and account access > Two-factor authentication.

#SoSoScholar2025 @SoSoValueCrypto
These Are The Things That I Observed About @SoSoValueCrypto 

Everyone knows SoSoValue for clean ETF dashboards and fast market intel, but the bigger play in 2025 is execution. Enter SoDEX, a decentralized exchange plugged directly into SoSoValue’s research stack, now in public testnet. 

Why this matters. Research without seamless execution leaves alpha on the table. SoDEX is designed to collapse that gap by putting institutional style analytics next to your order ticket, all inside one ecosystem. 

The engine. SoDEX testnet runs a central limit order book on a purpose built chain dubbed ValueChain. That means order transparency on chain with order book style price discovery and lower slippage compared with typical AMM designs. 

Scope on day one of testnet. Over a hundred spot pairs are live for simulated trading, with experiments in tokenized baskets and indices. That turns SoSoValue’s index know how into actual tradable markets. 

The data flywheel. SoSoValue already tracks daily spot Bitcoin and Ethereum ETF flows and market structure. Routing these signals to listing decisions, index baskets, and liquidity programs on SoDEX could create a real information to execution edge. 

Token utility gets teeth. SOSO started as an access and governance asset around research and indices. With SoDEX, the token extends into trading utility and incentives, aligning users who analyze, trade, and supply liquidity in one loop. Watch for how rewards are structured. 

Funding signal. In January 2025 the team raised fifteen million dollars to expand products and launch multi coin indices. That runway supports exchange grade infra and integrations that are costly to build and maintain. 

What to track next.
• ETF net inflow streaks versus SoDEX spot volumes and new pair performance
• Index methodology updates and any migration into live index markets on SoDEX
• App adoption trends from the mobile side feeding testnet users into mainnet at launch. 

Token supply reality check. Circulating supply is a little over one hundred fifteen million out of one billion, with scheduled unlocks to monitor. Map unlock dates against major SoDEX milestones to separate signal from noise around price. 

Compliance and product design. Tokenized indices and stock style markets are compelling, but they require careful venue design and jurisdiction aware access. Expect a phased rollout that prioritizes transparent on chain settlement with conservative perimeter features first. (Inference based on current testnet scope and public materials.) 

Risk sheet for 2025. Exchange centralization risks, bridge exploits, and narrative overreach remain live issues across crypto. SoDEX’s choice of on chain CLOB with explorer level auditability is one partial answer, but security reviews and stress tests will matter. 

How to get hands on. Join the testnet whitelist, claim from the faucet, and trade the sandbox to learn the UX and find gaps worth reporting. Early users can earn reputational and incentive upside while shaping mainnet polish. 

My base case. If SoSoValue lands clean integrations between ETF flow analytics, index research, and SoDEX order routing, it can become the first widely used research to execution loop in crypto that feels institutional but remains open to retail.

Final thought. Many exchanges talk about insight led trading. SoSoValue is building it as a product. If the testnet iteration pace holds and funding is deployed with focus, this could be one of 2025’s most interesting exchange launches to actually use.
